G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, §19**, conferring jurisdiction over civil actions where the damages claimed do not exceed $50,000.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Defendant’s failure to provide and maintain hot water constitutes an interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, in violation of **G.L. c. 186, §14**.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Pursuant to **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, §14**, a landlord may not "directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises," and a violation entitles the tenant to actual and statutory damages.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: Massachusetts law holds that the implied warranty of habitability, **G.L. c. 239, §8A**, and the covenant of quiet enjoyment are distinct, but both protect tenants from loss of basic services.

105 CMR 410.190.proposition: The provision of hot water is a basic service required under **105 CMR 410.190** of the State Sanitary Code; its absence conclusively establishes a breach of quiet enjoyment.

Winchester v. O'Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (192.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every Massachusetts tenancy.
Winchester v. O'Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (192.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses an implied obligation arising from the grant in the specific lease—namely, that the lessor would refrain from voluntarily undertaken acts that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises. It does not state or suggest that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every Massachusetts tenancy as a general rule. Instead, it treats the implication as flowing from the particular grant and then focuses on tort/nuisance and trespass theories distinct from the covenant of quiet enjoyment, expressly noting that the bill is not based solely on breach of the implied covenant.
Winchester v. O'Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (192.relevant_excerpt: “The ‘grant of any thing carries an implication, that the grantee shall have all that is necessary to the enjoyment of the grant, so far as the grantor has power to give it.’ … The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The bill is not based solely on breach of the implied covenant. The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant…”

Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.raw_text: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124 (1959)
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every Massachusetts tenancy.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.case_name: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, but it does so in the context of the express lease and services the landlord agreed to furnish. The court does not state or suggest that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every Massachusetts tenancy as a general rule; it simply treats the failure to furnish essential services in this particular commercial lease as a breach of that covenant. There is no broad statement about an implied covenant in all tenancies.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.relevant_excerpt: “Failure to furnish such services, at least if serious in extent and not excusable, deprives the lessee of a vital part of what the landlord knows the lessee must have in order to carry on his business. Such a failure constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment (see H. W. Robinson Carpet Co. v. Fletcher, 315 Mass. 350, 353…).”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Interference with essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case addresses constructive eviction and breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, but the facts and analysis concern excessive noise from a lounge, not interference with essential services such as heat or hot water. The opinion does briefly cite another case involving failure to supply heat, light, power, and elevator service as an example of a breach, but Blackett itself does not establish or focus on the specific proposition about heat or hot water. Thus, it is not direct authority for the claimed proposition, even though it is consistent with it by analogy.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services).”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Interference with essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that the landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season ‘constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.’ That is precisely an interference with an essential service (heat) being treated as a breach of the covenant. Thus the case squarely supports the proposition that interference with essential services such as heat (and by analogy hot water) constitutes a breach of the covenant.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’…and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The absence of hot water for an extended period, regardless of the landlord’s intent or efforts, constitutes a “substantial interference” with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the rented premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14’s reference to “water, hot water, heat” only in describing the statute’s scope, but the actual facts, analysis, and holding concern repeated flooding and sewage, not the absence of hot water. The court’s quiet-enjoyment analysis and its discussion of substantial interference are tied to flooding and sanitary code violations, and the opinion nowhere holds that an extended lack of hot water, regardless of the landlord’s intent or efforts, by itself constitutes a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus the case does not provide authority for the specific hot-water proposition stated.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “In relevant part, G. L. c. 186, § 14, as amended through St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, provides that: ‘Any lessor or landlord … who is required by law or by the express or implied terms of any contract or lease or tenancy at will to furnish water, hot water, heat, light, power, gas, elevator service, telephone service, janitor service or refrigeration service … who willfully or intentionally fails to furnish such water, hot water, heat, light, power, gas, elevator service, telephone service, janitor service or refrigeration service … or any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant… shall be punished… [and] shall also be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater….’”}

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The absence of hot water for an extended period, regardless of the landlord’s intent or efforts, constitutes a “substantial interference” with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the rented premises.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion does not address lack of hot water or utilities at all; it concerns whether a statutory lead paint violation, without proof of landlord fault, constitutes a violation of the quiet enjoyment statute. The court explicitly holds that at least negligent conduct and notice/foreseeability are required, rejecting strict liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14. That reasoning is inconsistent with the proposition that an extended absence of hot water constitutes substantial interference regardless of the landlord’s intent or efforts.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Massachusetts law holds that the implied warranty of habitability, **G.L. c. 239, §8A**, and the covenant of quiet enjoyment are distinct, but both protect tenants from loss of basic services.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the warranty of habitability and other landlord-tenant issues, but it does not mention G.L. c. 239, § 8A or the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it analyze the relationship between those concepts. It therefore does not establish that the implied warranty, § 8A, and quiet enjoyment are distinct yet all protect against loss of basic services. The case is about sanitary code compliance, security deposits, rent control, and habitability damages, not the doctrinal distinction referenced in the proposition.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability, maintaining that the judge failed both to use the "percentage reduction approach in calculating damages and to make specific findings regarding the extent of each violation. See McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977). Although a detailed explanation of the trial judge’s calculations would have been preferable, an approximate dollar amount is permissible; damages in rent abatement cases generally are not capable of precise measurement.

Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 353 Mass. 756.proposition: The provision of hot water is a basic service required under **105 CMR 410.190** of the State Sanitary Code; its absence conclusively establishes a breach of quiet enjoyment.
